conclusion: Two particles, A and B, start from rest at the same point and move in the same direction. The v-t graph shows velocities in terms of v0 and time in terms of t0.
The v-t graph shows the velocities of particles A and B over time.
The area under the curve for each particle represents the displacement from the starting point at any given time.
Particle A starts from rest, accelerates to 2v0 at t0, decelerates to zero at 2t0, accelerates to 2v0 at 3t0, and decelerates to zero at 4t0.
Particle B starts from rest, increases to v0 by 3t0, holds steady at v0 until 5t0, and decreases to zero by 6t0.

premise: Since both particles start from the same point and move in the same direction, their positions at any time t can be represented by the area under their respective velocity curves up to that time.
conclusion: The distance between them at any time t is the difference in the areas under their velocity curves.

premise: To find when they are farthest apart, I need to find when the difference in areas is maximized.
conclusion: The time when they are farthest apart is when the area under curve A minus the area under curve B is maximized.
Particle A accelerates quickly to a high velocity and then decreases, while particle B starts slowly and reaches a steady velocity later.

premise: Initially, particle A moves faster, so it will be ahead of particle B. As time progresses, particle B starts catching up.
conclusion: Eventually, they might get closer together or even meet.

premise: To find the time when they are farthest apart, I need to find the time t where the area under curve A minus the area under curve B is maximized.
conclusion: The farthest distance occurs at the red dot between 2t0 and 3t0.
